instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5_S0: What is PP5_S0? This is a typo of PP5V_S0 When you see PP5_S0, assume they meant to type PP5V_S0.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message:
Green/orange light
no liquid damage.

It takes 0.02 amps and  then jumps to 0.04a. And cycle repeats

ppbus = 8.60v
g3h = 3.445v  always stable.
ppvrtc = 3.343v pulses to 3.421v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.05v pulse to 3.80v
pp5vs4rs = 0v pulses to 0.038v
<SIGNAL>PP5_S0</SIGNAL> 0v pulses to 0.351v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.342v pulses to 0.350v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0v pulses to 0.590v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.342v pulses 0.064v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v pulses to 0.060v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.010v pulses to 0.130v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message: Does CPU VCore pulse as well?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message: Hmm ok inspect very closely for liquid or previous liquid damage near the SMC, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>. Remove J6100 for sure as well. Also check all rails for shorts might be a short causing the pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message:
Check for short on all secondary supplies.
Also check all voltages from pages 57/58.
If nothing found, remove <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> and report if something change.
See if pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulses.
Use o-scope if possible; your multimeter is not to good to catch pulses...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message:
Found shorted cap <CAPACITOR>C7553</CAPACITOR>
Now fan spins but nothing on screen.
no image/backlight
Now itt takes 0.24A.

cpu vcore 1.7V all other rails are present.

tried pram reset nothing.
usb mouse light up

replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> still the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message:
Mouse gets steady light if disconnect/reconnect "on the air"?
Better to test with USB OSX pendrive, with LED Link.

Try new BIOS, with clean ME of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message:
Steady light if disconnect/reconnect.
With new bios still the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message:
USB mouse can trick you.
Test with OSX pendrive.
See if LED Link flashes; that can confirm 100% activity...
